poem:
Title: "After Our Birds Have Flown"

Basking in the quiet of our feather-filmed nest,  
find ourselves, once two, now alone, then two again.  
A surplus of silence, a treasury of time,  
Armor of parenthood rustling off in the wind.  
A saucer of solitude steeping with intimacy,  
A teacup of time, brimming with possibility.  
Our nest emptied, becomes a new abode  
A cradle, for the loves we held, yet to unfold.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "True romance: how to keep the love alive when your kids have left home Couples whose grown children have finally left home – empty nesters, if you will – are visited by twin blessings that can quickly come to seem like challenges: a sudden surfeit of privacy and an unfamiliar excess of time. After years of wearing the armour of parenting, to find yourselves a couple again – alone together and at a loose end". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
